name: NewYorker
text:

text: “I just couldn’t sleep,” Max Kennedy, Jr., said, of what he witnessed while working on President Trump’s coronavirus task force. “I was so distressed and disturbed by what I’d seen.” https://t.co/PtlPDlRlP3

name: NewYorker
text: In our Monday crossword—our most challenging puzzle of the week—eight letters: Colonial housing? https://t.co/bbukHLGSBz

text: The many strategies devised to surmount the challenges of whole-roasting a chicken include grilling it with a beer can inside and cooking it “in the style of a toad.” https://t.co/P97EhjEZHO

name: NewYorker
text: The ragged end of Donald Trump's Presidency, if it comes, will be full of conflict and resentment, @mashagessen writes. There will be no orderly handover, no constructive transition—a disastrous prospect during a pandemic and a deep recession. https://t.co/UnlNO975Cc

name: NewYorker
text: “When you comment on a celebrity’s Instagram or Twitter, it’s unreciprocated. With Cameo, it’s about the exchange of love,” the app's founder said. https://t.co/l73toVYU51

name: NewYorker
text: The awfulness of the latest Trump revelations is no less awful for having been both anticipated and completely consistent with what we already suspected, @sbg1 writes. https://t.co/jEVhktM0YV

name: NewYorker
text: Recent poll findings suggest President Trump is still confronting the same basic challenge that the Republican Party faced in the 2018 midterms: a majority of voters don’t like the President or approve of the job he is doing. https://t.co/Ibfzedro35

name: NewYorker
text: The past never leaves us, Jeffrey Eugenides seems to say in "The Virgin Suicides;" it just doubles and exposes, always shifting out of our grasp. https://t.co/pzZmPg4nGN

name: NewYorker
text: Robert Mueller declined to issue a grand-jury subpoena for Donald Trump’s testimony, and he excluded from his report a conclusion that Trump had committed crimes. These decisions are the most revealing features of Mueller’s tenure, Jeffrey Toobin writes. https://t.co/FUpnHBSVsx

name: NewYorker
text: .@gmochkofsky on how the term "Latinx" is an attempt to label varied communities that have one thing in common: the ways in which they’ve faced racial discrimination. https://t.co/iHqBtkKslw

name: NewYorker
text: The struggling performers who are the subject of “Tales from a Hard City” are endowed with an authentic illumination that their professional endeavors only dimly reflect—but that comes to the fore brightly in the documentary. https://t.co/uVMOoC7hWO

name: NewYorker
text: Thelonious Monk’s artistry is woven into the very core of jazz history. “Palo Alto,” a new release, offers its own distinctive and illuminating pleasures. https://t.co/lk8AJ88fPh

name: NewYorker
text: “It’s O.K., I told my father, through the contact of my ﬁngertips to his febrile skin. You can let go. It will be O.K. We will be O.K.” Michael Chabon on losing his father, and what they shared. https://t.co/SlEpeU8IWL

name: NewYorker
text: Minutes before her mother's nursing facility kicked its patients' aides out, @JiayangFan was on FaceTime with her, desperately trying to reassure her. "It was then that I took the screenshots that later spread across Chinese social media," Fan writes. https://t.co/gG6dTGZNmS

name: NewYorker
text: On this week's Politics and More podcast, David Remnick discusses some of the pitfalls in the election process, including the possibility of hacking, the contention around mail-in voting, and more. Listen here. https://t.co/rEbBnyVfda

text:

text: The norms of political conduct, already fading at the turn of the century, now seem to have disappeared altogether, and the aftermath of the 2020 election has the potential to make 2000 look like a mere skirmish. https://t.co/6JjPA5MlgA

name: NewYorker
text: In the preface to her collection of short fiction, “Telling Stories,” Joan Didion elaborates on her time as a junior editor at Vogue. “We were connoisseurs of synonyms,” she writes. “We were collectors of verbs.” https://t.co/c839fG91A9

text: “I gave him a smile, as if everything were all good, then started in with some more about the virus. I would try to make a bad situation diverting.” A short story by Lorrie Moore. https://t.co/RjSd2Z96Iy

name: NewYorker
text: In 1800, an average American would have lived and died never having encountered a single manufactured candy. Today, that average American ingests more than 19 teaspoons of added sugar every day. Can we curb our obsession? https://t.co/vt3IP3huIv

name: NewYorker
text: In the 14 billion years between the big bang and the autumn of 1957, space was pristine. Today, the Earth is surrounded by a growing cloud of man-made debris—and any small bit of it might lead to disaster. https://t.co/9KNYXJWVvc

text: “What operating system are you working on? Ask the gnome.” An encounter with tech support, by Noah Baumbach. https://t.co/hUMpQ0hkxE

text: In 2000, the recount struggle came as a surprise to both Presidential candidates. This year, each side has mustered for a legal ﬁght that began months ago and may well continue long after November 3rd.  https://t.co/NOC679db5e

text: Max Kennedy, Jr., described the Trump Administration’s coronavirus response as “a family office meets organized crime, melded with ‘Lord of the Flies.’ It was a government of chaos.” https://t.co/h8VQRw2WjK
